text:
Summarize (Orchestrating the Discussion)

Solutions and Strategies

Have students share their strategies and solutions. Share number lines and chip boards. Connect the models to the symbols in the number sentences. Focus on the generalizations the students find when adding integers. (Portrayal)

Making the Mathematics Explicit

As students are sharing their solutions and strategies the questions posed should revolve around getting students to be able to verbalize an algorithm for adding integers. (Language)

Suggested Questions

  • How do you solve integer addition problems in which both signs are the same? (When both signs are the same, add the absolute values of the numbers and give the answer the same sign as the addends.)
  • How do you solve integer addition problems in which the signs of the numbers are different? (When the signs are different, subtract the absolute values of the numbers and give the answer the same sign as the addend with the greater absolute value.)
  • Which model better represents this situation: the chip model or the number line model? Why do you think this? (Answers will vary. Let students use either model depending on the situation.)
  • In What If Situation A, did changing the order if the number change the sum? (No, remind students that this is the Commutative Property and it holds true for integers.)
  • How did you use the models for What If Situation B? (The number line model is more conducive to showing adding with fractions and decimals.)

This is a conversation from one classroom: (Problem Solving Environment)

Teacher: How can you predict whether the sum of two integers is 0, positive, or negative?

Jeff: We predicted that if the signs are the same you just have that sign for the sum. However, when there is one of each sign, we aren’t sure. We tried several with our chip board but couldn’t find a reason why the sum was red or black. (negative or positive)

Teacher: Can you show some of the work your group did with your chip boards?

Jeff: Here are some chipboards we did:

Teacher: What do other groups think about the chipboard idea that Jeff’s group has started?

Kathy: We did that too and did several more. When we looked at the number sentence we saw a pattern. The color with the largest number of chips on the board was always the sign of the sum. Like in 4 + - 6 there are more red chips than black so the sum was going to be negative.

Teacher: Is this always true?

Tatiana: Yes. We found the same thing but we also found out that when you have two different colors if you just subtract the numbers then look at which color had the most you have the full answer. Using the one Kathy talked about 4 + -6. You just subtract 6 and 4 which is 2 and since there are more red chips than black chips the sum is -2.

Jeff: You guys are right! That works for all of the chipboards we did.

Teacher: What if we used the number line model for the situations Jeff started us looking at?

Yvonne: We used number lines. Let me try it with 4 + -6. (Yvonne draws it on the board) We found the same idea that Teri was talking about. When the signs are different you are subtracting because you end up starting in one direction on the number line and then reversing the direction with the number that is a different sign. It was like you were taking some of those away that you first did.

Teacher: Can someone else explain the algorithm that Tatiana and Yvonne are showing with the two models?

Shawn: Both of them are saying that if you are adding numbers that have different signs you can subtract the numbers and the sum will have the sign of the largest numeral.

If you collected number sentences from Investigation 1 have them apply their new thinking about finding sums to their number sentences to verify their conclusions.

Now What Do Students Know

Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions.

Reflecting on Student Learning

Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.

  • What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know Question?
  1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?
  • How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this unit? The next unit?
